ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class both shed light on the basics of venture capital -- everything from unit economics, to valuation, investment process, macro trends, sectors of focus, etc -- and also how to think about VC in the context of emerging markets. The class taught us about investment strategy and about life preparation -- each class had a different guest speaker from a different fund who was able to talk to us about their experiences, theses, and how they think about a lot of the concept we were discussing in class.
So many. From valuation to terminology, this course was a real-world guide to working in venture capital.
Basics of venture investing with a focus on understanding term sheets and unit economics, lots of close knit conversations with VCs in industry from different backgrounds

Venture capital decision-making fundamentals (articulating risks behind investments, justifying investments, identifying macro trends), venture capital in emerging markets, venture capital mechanics (cap tables, term sheets, valuations, unit economics).
I learned about basic VC concepts (term sheets, TAM, etc), trends in VC, and how to analyze companies particularly in emerging markets
This course taught me about how venture capitalists succeed and make critical decisions

I learned about financial models, moats, unit economics, scale, valuations, boards, unique facets of emerging markets, how to write an investment memo, how to think like an investor or entrepreneur, how to live a holistic and fulfilling career.
Better professional understanding of the industry and how to conduct analysis
So many. This was one of the greatest courses I took at Yale.

I have always been set on working on public markets after I graduate, but this class introduced me to the possibilities of VC work. We went over the basics of VC (cap tables, etc.), spoke to amazingly accomplished people in the field in nearly every class (guest speakers), and got to do a deep dive into a particular topic we were interested in. I came out of this course with a much more solid understanding of VC in emerging markets and a clearer idea of how I wish to structure my career in the near future.
I learned so much in this class about emerging markets; the mechanics, basics, and skills required to be a successful early-stage investor; and invaluable life lessons.

Overview of the venture capital lifecycle, fund structure, and the typical term sheet; differences and similarities between VC in the US and in emerging markets; deep dive into various startups, their products and unit economics. How to think about evaluating startup investments as a VC and how to evaluate funds as a founder.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course were absolutely the readings assigned and the guest speakers that came each week to talk about their experiences in relation to the topics at hand. We learned a ton about not only different fund strategies, but also about how they thought about the topics we were discussing in class. There were debates during class discussions, which were great to push our thinking outside what we might have originally thought when we were doing the assigned readings. The course could have been improved by actually applying a lot of what we were talking about and learning to an actual case -- some kind of investment analysis on a company of choice (or assigned) to see how we could think critically in an investment scenario.

Strengths: everything. Ishan was helpful, brilliant, caring, and welcoming. He designed an incredible syllabus and brought in amazing guest speakers.
Weaknesses: n/a

I wish there was more asynchronous work! Seminar was easily dominated by the same voices with little time to counteract/anticipate the flow of conversations. Making reading responses visible to the entire class and encouraging student engagement with written work + submitting questions before each session would have made the seminar a lot better

Strengths: I think the Q&A nature of the course is its biggest strength. Being able to ask Ishan anything and everything about his investments, his experiences, his thoughts on industry trends was an amazing experience. Also, being able to interact with so many guest speakers (who were all amazing--world-class VCs and C-suite of unicorns) was awesome. 

Weaknesses: NONE! Couldn't have enjoyed the course more.
Strengths: really interesting class, Ishan is super knowledgeable and facilitated conversation, great guest speakers
I particularly enjoyed that this course had a variety of phenomenal speakers who could share real world insights which were pertinent what we were learning
Ishan is an amazing professor with deep insights on VC. He has a vast network of investors and entrepreneurs to choose as guest lecturers. The course was one of the best I've taken at Yale.
Amazing guest speakers on a weekly basis
Would enjoy even more technical assignments and course content
Nothing. Ishan should continue to be a professor here. Yale needs to bring him back.

Strengths: Ishan is a super engaging instructor! He responds to all of our questions with genuine answers and opinions. I loved the fact that we got to speak to SO many young individuals who are in VC or starting their own companies. I also loved the selection of books we were assigned to read. 

Weaknesses: This is not something feasible this year, but the only thing I hope this seminar can change is to be in person.

Strengths: very informal discussion that made the class feel more like a chat than an awkward putting your hand up for the sake of participating class, very supportive, understanding, and engaged professor, incredible guest speakers, relevant readings and assignments

One suggestion I would have for the class would be for the guest speaker sessions to be more structured - perhaps with students coming prepared with a small assignment to talk about with the guest speaker rather than asking questions that end up going in many different directions and that are not always linear.

Strengths: the focus on emerging markets is really interesting and quite different from within the US. Fund strategies and structures are also evolving, and founders need to take quite a different approach in overseas markets. The guest speakers were great: hearing directly from investors and operators is incredibly valuable.

Weaknesses: the course is by necessity quite broad, although you get a chance to dive into a specific topic with the paper. We went deep on a few verticals like emerging markets fintech and within a few markets, but I sometimes wished for a more in-depth case study and discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The best practices in this course were the in class discussions/debates and the guest speakers that came to talk about their perspectives and thoughts on the topics that we were discussing. Each week, a different guest speaker from a different VC firm would join us to give their thoughts on the topics we were discussing/had read for that class and we were able to ask questions about their experiences and background. It was an open forum discussion and then the class would continue the discussion after their left and we would debate out the topics at hand. It was awesome. The one thing that I would have liked to see more of in the class was a bit more structure -- and for Ishan to offer his opinions/insights more often.
it was perfectly done
Zoom seminar worked well
Allowing speakers to attend is an example of thus
Ishan did a good job at navigating a Zoom seminar. He also leveraged Zoom to bring in guest lecturers from around the world.
Overall, this course had a great virtual learning environment. Ishan and the guest speakers were all very available to students outside of class via Zoom.
The ability to bring guest speakers from all around the country was great!
Guest speakers were excellent and discussion worked great over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone looking to learn more about VC, emerging markets, investing, or macro analysis, This is one of the most interesting classes that I have taken at Yale and the class discussions and debates were some of the best I've ever bee a part of.
in a heartbeat
Yes if interested in VC in any form, especially if youre an international/have close ties to the studied markets

1000000% take it! Best course I've ever taken at Yale. Venture Investing in Emerging Markets was by far my favorite part of the week. Ishan, and this course, changed my life! I've never gotten so much out of a course at Yale.
Would definitely recommend this to anyone interested in VC, tech, entrepreneurship or emerging markets
This course is great for anybody who seeks to understand the intricacies of venture capital. It also helps give insights into startup scenes in emerging markets.
I would highly recommend this course, especially if Ishan is teaching it!
100% take it if its taught again and you are interested in venture capital
Absolutely - definitely take this class if you are looking for a fun engaging and stress-free course! You get the chance to meet some amazing people and learn about VC!
Yes. The course is not only practical to vc but also explores greater philosophical discussion
absolutely. If youre interested in emerging markets or the venture space, this is a MUST TAKE.

YES! 100% without a doubt! If Ishan teaches this again, don't hesitate to take it. This course is unlike other seminars at Yale. You walk away with a comprehensive overview of VC, a general understanding of how EM investing differs from Americas/Europe investing, and most importantly, a clearer blueprint of how you want to structure your career. Ishan and all the guest speakers are super approachable and available to chat outside of class. I took this course with a 12 hour time zone difference at 3 AM my time, and it was absolutely worth it.

I would recommend this class to any student interested in entrepreneurship or venture capital. Every class felt like attending an informal coffee chat with the professor and other students. I learned so much from just listening to my professor and peers and exchanging ideas rather than completing several assignments for the sake of completing them.
Yes, if you're at all interested in being a founder or investor with an eye towards emerging markets and their unique challenges and opportunities!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual lecture and reading responses, final 15-25 page paper and paper proposal
virtual guest speakers, etc.
Virtual seminar, reading responses, final paper.
Virtual seminar with a lot of guest speakers.
